results.deck: Based on the syndicated comic strip of the same name, Garfield follows the eponymous curmudgeonly cat as he tries to clean up the house before his owner comes home.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield (not to be confused with the unreleased Atari 2600 game and the 2011 mobile game of the same name) is a 3D third-person action-adventure game developed by The Code Monkeys and published by Hip for the PlayStation 2, exclusively in Europe, on November 19, 2004. It was later ported to the PC and released on May 17, 2005 in both Europe and North America.

The first 3D game based on the comic strip of the same name, Garfield has players controlling the eponymous orange tabby cat of the same name as he runs around the house and uses a vacuum cleaner to clean up the house before his owner Jon Arbuckle comes home (lest he gets put on a diet).

Gameplay

Players control the eponymous feline Garfield and his attempts to clean up his owner Jon's house before Jon gets home from grocery shopping. The game is a loose, open-ended adventure game where Garfield must reach and collect various misplaced items around the house and put them back in their correct locations. This is done with the use of a vacuum cleaner, "sucking" up items and "blowing" them back into their correct spots.

Players are limited to a few rooms initially, but after fully restoring one room the player is given a key to a new room. Most of the early unlocked rooms are on the ground floor, moving to the first floor and then finally outside, the attic and the basement. Players can also collect puzzle pieces for an in-game puzzle, as well as partake in several mini-games which will net rewards such as house items and more puzzle pieces. The game has a generous time limit.

The game also features an in-game "classic video game" cartridge, which once restored to its proper place can be played. It's a Columns-esque puzzle game.
results.name: Garfield

results.aliases:
Garfield: Grande, Gordo Y Peludo
Teodoro - Vita da Gatti
results.deck: Garfield must rescue his girlfriend Arlene from the city pound in this puzzle solving action-adventure.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield: Big, Fat, Hairy Deal is an action/adventure game developed by Softek International and published by The Edge for Amiga, Amstrad CPC, Atari ST, Commodore 64, and ZX Spectrum.

Gameplay

Garfield: Big, Fat, Hairy Deal has players taking on the role of Garfield. It is up to Garfield to try and rescue Arlene from the pound.

Players progress through the game by collecting and using various items found in the environment.

results.name: Garfield: Big, Fat, Hairy Deal

results.deck: When the love interest of everyone's favorite lazy tabby cat gets impounded, it's up to him and his pal Odie to rescue her in this 3D action-adventure platformer for the PS2.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield: Saving Arlene (known in Japan as Garfield: Arleene o Sukue, which is loosely translated to "Garfield: Save Arlene") is a 3D third-person action-adventure platformer developed by EKO and published for the PlayStation 2 by Hip (in Europe sometime in 2006) and Titus (in Japan on April 27, 2006).

The second 3D platformer based on the Garfield comic strip, Saving Arlene has players controlling the titular orange tabby cat as he, with the help of his pal Odie, sets out to rescue Garfield's love interest (Arlene) from the animal pound.

It received a sequel a year later, titled Garfield: Lasagna World Tour.

A US release of Saving Arlene was planned and announced by The Game Factory, but the release was canceled.
results.name: Garfield: Saving Arlene

results.deck: The comic strip cat's first dedicated handheld adventure, in which Garfield searches for his stolen teddy bear Pooky while eating as many floating hot dogs as he can find.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield: The Search for Pooky is a 2D side-scrolling platformer developed by InterActive Vision and published for the Game Boy Advance by KE (in Europe sometime in late 2004) and The Game Factory (in North America on November 14, 2005).

Based on the Garfield comic strip, The Search for Pooky has players controlling Garfield as he searches for his beloved teddy bear Pooky, which was stolen by a trio of mice. The game is unique as it uses slightly-altered scans of the source material for the in-game art.
results.name: Garfield: The Search for Pooky

results.deck: Play mini-games and learn about cats at the same time in this edutainment game.
results.name: Garfield's Mad About Cats

results.deck: A video game tie-in with the movie of the same name. Features a distinct lack of both Bill Murray and Tim Curry.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (known in Europe as Garfield 2) is a 3D action-adventure platformer developed by Asobo and published by The Game Factory for the PlayStation 2 and PC in both Europe (on October 6, 2006) and North America (on October 17, 2006).

A video game tie-in with the 2006 feature film of the same name (itself based on the Garfield comic strip), A Tail of Two Kitties is set in the United Kingdom as players control orange tabby cat Garfield (who is mistaken for Prince XII: another orange tabby cat who was recently left the ownership of a grand estate). He must foil the plans of Lord Dargis, who's trying to take the estate for himself.

It also received a handheld version by Two Tribes for the Nintendo DS (with the European version released on August 25, 2006 and the North American version released on October 17, 2006). This game's plot is different as Garfield must instead make his way to the castle.
results.name: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties

results.deck: Everybody's favorite fat feline becomes trapped inside his television set! Can he progress through numerous TV shows to escape TV Land?
results.description:
Overview

Garfield: Caught in the Act is a 2D side-scrolling platformer developed by Sega InterActive and published by Sega for the Sega Genesis on October 1995. A handheld version was created by Novotrade for the Sega Game Gear on November 1995.

Based on the comic strip of the same name (and loosely based on Garfield: His 9 Lives), Caught in the Act features hand-drawn sprites by the artists at Paws (namely the strip's creator Jim Davis). Players control the eponymous furry feline as he becomes trapped inside his poorly-reassembled television set by a sentient set of spare pieces (known as the Glitch). He must navigate numerous TV shows (representing various points in time) and find a way to escape.

An enhanced version was later developed for PCs (running Windows) by Point of View in March 1996. This version was released exclusively in North America by Expert as part of the Sega PC Collection and was known in the box art as "Garfield: Garfield in TV Land!". This version features redbook audio, enhanced graphics, and a new level arrangement based on the GG version (with a new exclusive level). It was later bundled with Sonic & Knuckles Collection and Baku Baku Animal as the Sonic & Garfield Pack.

In addition, the Genesis version received an exclusive three-level standalone expansion that was digitally distributed through the Sega Channel accessory. Dubbed "Garfield: The Lost Levels", some of these levels appeared in the GG version. As the accessory was discontinued, there is currently no way to play this expansion.

It is the last game developed by the Sega InterActive division.

Levels

GEN Version

  • Count Slobula's Castle
  • Revenge of Orangebeard
  • Cave Cat 3,000,000 BC
  • Catsablanca
  • The Curse of Cleofatra
  • Season Finale

The following levels made up the downloadable "Lost Levels" expansion:

  • Bonehead the Barbarian
  • Slobbin Hood
  • ???

GG Version

  • Cave Cat 3,000,000 B.C.
  • The Curse of Cleofatra
  • Bonehead the Barbarian
  • Count Slobula's Castle
  • Revenge of Orangebeard
  • Slobbin Hood
  • Catsablanca
  • Television Wasteland

PC Version

  • Cave Cat 3,000,000 BC
  • The Curse of Cleofatra
  • Count Slobula's Castle
  • Revenge of Orangebeard
  • Catsablanca
  • Alien Landscape
  • Season Finale
results.name: Garfield: Caught in the Act

results.deck: Follow the lasagna-eating Mondays-hating tabby cat as he follows scenes from the 2007 CGI movie of the same name.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield Gets Real is a minigame collection developed by Gravity-i and published for the Nintendo DS in North America (by DSI on July 21, 2009) and Europe (by ZOO on August 28, 2009).

A video game tie-in with the 2007 CGI film of the same name, Garfield Gets Real follows the eponymous tabby cat through both the Comic Strip World and the Real World. As players perform scenes from the movie, the game scores them as if they were making a "Director's Cut" version of the movie's DVD.

The game is broken up into three sequences: one where Garfield must move left and right to catch things, a side-scrolling platformer, and a dancing mini-game.
results.name: Garfield Gets Real

results.deck: Released in Japan only, A Week of Garfield is a Famicom game where the lazy orange cat must rescue Odie from neighborhood ne'er-do-wells. Its extremely poor quality may have kept it from being released overseas.
results.description:
Japan's Favorite American Cat

Story
When Odie gets dognapped by a local feline ruffian,  Jon Arbuckle awakes Garfield to put him to the task. Too bad for Garfield that it's Monday -- and that the week ahead of him will be his most treacherous ever. In A Week of Garfield, the lazy orange cat must frantically search for keys and invincibility lasagna while avoiding dangerous spiders and mice.

It's Monday. Odie awaits on Sunday. Can Garfield survive?

Gameplay
The gameplay of A Week of Garfield centers around Garfield's frantic search for the keys that allow him access to the next areas. The keys are inexplicably hidden in the background and can only be found by jumping or moving onto where they are located, causing them to appear and be obtainable. Garfield can also throw bones and other objects at the mice, spiders, and cat bosses that will pursue him to the death across his week of hell.

Details
A Week of Garfield was only released in Japan in 1989 for the Famicom. It was developed by Mars Corp. and published by Towa Chiki. Apparently rights issues, or perhaps even the poor quality of the game, kept it from reaching native shores. The Japanese box lists it as being a part of the "American Comic Action" genre.

Also, the game's instruction booklet states that the story takes place in New York City, though in the Jim Davis comic no specific city is mentioned, not to mention Jon Arbuckle's house is seemingly in a generic Middle-American suburb devoid of the urban trappings of NYC.
results.name: A Week of Garfield

results.deck: Garfield has over-indulged before bed and as a result is stuck in his nightmare. Help Garfield out in this DS platformer developed by Shin'en Multimedia.
results.name: Garfield's Nightmare

results.deck: A toolbox "game" which lets you create comic strips and images using various characters and props from the Garfield cartoons.
results.name: Create with Garfield!

results.deck: Unreleased Atari 2600 Garfield game. Among the things Garfield must go through in this game are flying hamburgers, flowerpots, & tons of Odies.
results.description: The ROM is currently available as legal freeware on the internet, as programmer Steve Woita was given permission by Jim Davis and Paws Inc. to distribute the ROM.
results.name: Garfield

results.deck: Garfield's second handheld adventure puts him through nine levels of traditional platforming.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield and his Nine Lives is a 2D side-scrolling platformer developed by Lucky Jump and published by The Game Factory for the Game Boy Advance on May 5, 2006 in Europe and on May 10, 2006 in North America.

Based on the Garfield comic strip, Nine Lives has players controlling Garfield through nine levels of standard platforming fare. Unlike Garfield: The Search for Pooky, this game uses hand-drawn pixel art (rather than altered scans from the comic strip itself).

Levels

  1. Arbuckle Farm
  2. Haunted House
  3. The Circus
  4. Spiders in the Sewers
  5. Up a Tree
  6. Alley Cat
  7. Obedience Class
  8. Dr. Dupes and the Odie Clones
  9. Kitchen Cat
results.name: Garfield and his Nine Lives

results.deck: Based off the movie of the same name, Garfield's FunFest is a video game for the Nintendo DS.
results.name: Garfield's FunFest

results.deck: The Garfield Show - Threat of the Space Lasagna is a videogame for the Nintendo Wii. It is based on the TV show of the same title.
results.name: The Garfield Show: Threat of the Space Lasagna

results.deck: The sequel to Garfield: Saving Arlene, Lasagna World Tour throws the fat, lazy tabby cat throughout the world on a treasure hunt (just so that he can get a lifetime's worth of lasagna).
results.description:
Overview

Garfield: Lasagna World Tour is a 3D third-person action-adventure platformer developed by EKO and published for the PlayStation 2 by Blast! (in Europe on November 30, 2007) and Conspiracy (in North America on June 27, 2008).

Based on the Garfield comic strip, Lasagna World Tour is a sequel to the 2006 platformer Garfield: Saving Arlene. Players control the titular orange tabby cat as he, with the help of his pal Odie, sets out throughout the world on a treasure hunt (in order to obtain a lifetime's worth of lasagna).

Along with minor gameplay improvements, this sequel includes numerous power-ups in the form of costumes (including a soccer player for kicking Odie around and a cowboy for shooting obstacles with toy darts).
results.name: Garfield Lasagna World Tour

results.deck: Published by PC Treasures INC. Garfield It's All About Reading and Phonics is a educational game for the PC.
results.name: Garfield It's All About Reading and Phonics Volume 1

results.deck: Jon has unleashed a pet-cleaning robot in the house. Can Odie and Garfield outrun this mechanical monster?
results.description: Oddly, Garfield cannot be unlocked for play until level 5; the player must use Odie exclusively until then.
results.name: Garfield's Escape

results.aliases:
Garfield 2: Winter's Tail - A Mid Supper Night's Dream
Garfield: Sueños de Invierno
results.deck: Mini-game collection based on dreams of Garfield.
results.description:
Overview

Garfield: Winter's Tail is a minigame collection developed by Softek International and published by The Edge for Amiga, Amstrad CPC, Atari ST, Commodore 64, and ZX Spectrum.

Gameplay

Garfield has fallen asleep next to the refrigerator and is now dreaming three food related dreams. Players try and make Garfield's dream happy.

The three different dreams represent the game's three different minigames. The three minigames are: Skiing, a chocolate factory, and ice skating.
